2025-12-10 16:47:28,298 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 40-year-old businessman who was previously well is brought into the emergency department by his assistant with a complaint of left-sided weakness after a chiropractic neck manipulation. He has never felt like this before. Past medical history is insignificant. His blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg, pulse 86/min, respiratory rate 13/min, temperature 36.8°C (98.2°F). A T2-weighted MRI shows a left C5 hemicord lesion. The patient is treated with cervical immobilization, a course of steroids, and physical therapy. What other finding will most likely be seen in this patient?

[A] : Spastic paralysis at the level of lesion
[B] : Right-sided Horner's syndrome
[C] : Contralateral corticospinal tract involvement
[D] : Right-sided analgesia
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient has a left C5 hemicord lesion, which means that the injury is affecting the spinal cord at the level of the fifth cervical vertebra on the left side. The spinal cord is responsible for transmitting signals between the brain and the rest of the body.

[A]. Spastic paralysis at the level of lesion - This is a likely finding because the corticospinal tract, which carries motor signals from the brain to the spinal cord and then to the muscles, is affected. When the corticospinal tract is damaged, it can result in spastic paralysis, which is characterized by increased muscle tone and reflexes.

[B]. Right-sided Horner's syndrome - Horner's syndrome is characterized by ptosis (drooping eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side of the face. It is caused by disruption of the sympathetic nerves. However, the sympathetic fibers that could cause Horner's syndrome run along the top of the spinal cord and are not typically affected by a hemicord lesion at the C5 level.

[C]. Contralateral corticospinal tract involvement - This is not likely because the corticospinal tract is ipsilateral (on the same side) as it descends from the brain to the spinal cord. A lesion at the C5 level would affect the corticospinal tract on the same side, not the contralateral (opposite) side.

[D]. Right-sided analgesia - Analgesia refers to a loss of sensation. The spinothalamic tract, which carries pain and temperature sensations, crosses over (decussates) to the opposite side of the spinal cord shortly after entering. Therefore, a lesion at the C5 level would not typically cause right-sided analgesia because the spinothalamic tract would have already crossed over to the opposite side.

Given these considerations, the most likely additional finding in this patient with a left C5 hemicord lesion would be spastic paralysis at the level of the lesion due to the involvement of the corticospinal tract.

So, the answer is [A]. Spastic paralysis at the level of lesion.<|end|>

[D] : Varicocele

[C] : Bernard-Soulier disease
[D] : Scurvy
<|end|><|assistant|> The infant presents with a history of spontaneous nosebleeds, multiple bruising, and petechiae without any trauma. The vital signs are relatively stable, but the physical examination reveals signs of a bleeding disorder, such as pale skin, petechiae, and ecchymosis.

The complete blood count shows a low hemoglobin and hematocrit, which indicates anemia, but the platelet count is elevated, which is not typical for most forms of anemia. The leukocyte count is within normal limits, and the differential does not show any abnormalities.

The coagulation tests, including partial thromboplastin time (PTT), prothrombin time (PT), and international normalized ratio (INR), are within normal limits, which suggests that the coagulation pathway is functioning properly. The fibrinogen level is also normal.

The blood smear findings of hypochromia, poikilocytosis, and large platelets are indicative of a platelet disorder. The normal platelet aggregation test with ristocetin rules out von Willebrand disease, as this test is used to diagnose von Willebrand disease by assessing the ability of platelets to aggregate in the presence of the antibiotic ristocetin.

Given the normal coagulation tests and the abnormal platelet morphology, we can rule out von Willebrand disease (A) and Bernard-Soulier disease (C), which is characterized by a deficiency of the glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex on the platelet surface, leading to abnormal platelet adhesion.

Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia (B) is a rare genetic platelet disorder where the platelets lack the ability to properly aggregate due to a deficiency of the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa complex. This would explain the normal platelet aggregation test with ristocetin and the increased bleeding time.

Scurvy (D) is caused by a deficiency of vitamin C, which is necessary for the synthesis of collagen. While scurvy can lead to bleeding due to weakened blood vessel walls, it is less likely in this case given the normal coagulation tests and the specific findings on the blood smear.

Therefore, the most likely cause of this patient's condition is Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia.

So, the answer is [B]. Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia.<|end|>

2025-12-10 16:48:38,410 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A laboratory primarily involved with studying cellular proofreading mechanisms is investigating the question of whether the ribosome can recognize a mischarged amino acid and still be incorporated into the growing peptide. In order to do so, they biochemically charge a Lys-tRNA with valine instead of lysine and insert the tRNA into the cell. They design an mRNA sequence that contains only codons for lysine. Which of the following will most likely occur?

[A] : The ribosome will recognize the mischarged tRNA and prevent its incorporation by removing the valine
[B] : The mischarged tRNA with valine will be incorporated in the codons that specificy for lysine
[C] : The mischarged tRNA will be degraded by the proteasome
[D] : The mischarged tRNA will be removed by the lysyl-tRNA synthetase
<|end|><|assistant|> The ribosome is responsible for translating mRNA into a polypeptide chain by adding amino acids to the growing peptide chain in the order specified by the mRN[A]. Each tRNA molecule carries a specific amino acid and has an anticodon that pairs with a codon on the mRN[A].

In the scenario described, a tRNA molecule that is supposed to carry lysine has been chemically modified to carry valine instead. This tRNA is then inserted into the cell. The mRNA sequence contains only codons for lysine.

When the ribosome encounters a codon for lysine on the mRNA, it will attempt to pair the tRNA with the anticodon to incorporate the correct amino acid, lysine, into the growing peptide chain. However, because the tRNA in question is mischarged with valine, the ribosome will not be able to recognize the mismatch between the tRNA anticodon and the mRNA codon. This mismatch will likely result in the ribosome stalling or skipping the incorporation of the tRNA into the peptide chain.

The ribosome does not have a mechanism to remove incorrectly charged tRNAs during translation. Instead, the mischarged tRNA would be recognized as incorrect by the proofreading mechanisms of the cell, and it would be targeted for degradation. The lysyl-tRNA synthetase, which is responsible for charging tRNA with lysine, would not be able to correct this error because the tRNA is already in the cell and the error is not in the charging process but in the tRNA itself.

So, the answer is [A]. The ribosome will recognize the mischarged tRNA and prevent its incorporation by removing the valine.<|end|>

[C] : Random error
[D] : Effect modification

[D]. Effect modification occurs when the effect of the main exposure on the outcome is modified by the presence of another variable. In this case, the CD4+ cell count is the modifying variable that changes the relationship between cART adherence and DLBCL risk. Therefore, the difference in the relationship between cART adherence and DLBCL risk across the two CD4+ cell count strata is an example of effect modification.

2025-12-10 16:49:20,611 - INFO - question 193/1273 answer:D correct_answer:D True
2025-12-10 16:49:27,245 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> During a Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection, Th1 cells secrete a factor capable of stimulating phagosome-lysosome fusion within macrophages. In addition, the secreted factors help activate macrophages to produce mediators such as NO, which are capable of destroying the invading pathogen. Furthermore, activation of the macrophages by the secreted factor eventually leads to the formation of a tubercle. Which of the following factors is secreted by Th1 cells and responsible for these actions?

[A] : IL-4
[B] : TNF-alpha
[C] : IFN-gamma
[D] : Histamine
<|end|><|assistant|> During a Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection, the immune response is crucial for controlling the spread of the bacteria. Th1 cells, a subset of T helper cells, play a significant role in this response. They are known for their ability to activate macrophages, which are cells that engulf and destroy pathogens.

The factor secreted by Th1 cells that stimulates phagosome-lysosome fusion within macrophages is IFN-gamma (Interferon-gamma). This cytokine is critical for the activation of macrophages, enhancing their ability to kill intracellular pathogens like Mycobacterium tuberculosis. IFN-gamma also promotes the formation of granulomas, which are organized structures of immune cells that help contain the infection. The granulomas eventually lead to the formation of tubercles, which are the hallmark of tuberculosis infection.

IL-4 is typically associated with Th2 responses and is more involved in humoral immunity and allergic responses. TNF-alpha is also involved in the immune response and can contribute to granuloma formation, but it is not the primary factor secreted by Th1 cells for the activation of macrophages in this context. Histamine is mainly involved in allergic reactions and is not a cytokine secreted by Th1 cells.

So, the answer is [C]. IFN-gamma.<|end|>
2025-12-10 16:49:27,245 - INFO - question 194/1273 answer:C correct_answer:C True

[B] : Conversion of porphobilinogen to hydroxymethylbilane
[C] : Conversion of aminolevulinic acid to porphobilinogen
[D] : Conversion of uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III

Lead poisoning interferes with several enzymatic steps in the heme synthesis pathway. One of the key enzymes affected by lead is delta-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALAD), which is responsible for the conversion of delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) to porphobilinogen. 2025-12-10 16:49:43,668 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A group of researchers conducted a study to determine whether there is an association between folic acid supplementation before pregnancy and autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in offspring. The researchers retrospectively surveyed 200 mothers with children diagnosed with ASD during the first 4 years of life and 200 mothers with healthy children. All participants were interviewed about their prenatal consumption of folic acid using standardized questionnaires. A 94% response rate was obtained from the surveys. The study ultimately found that folic acid supplementation was associated with lower rates of ASD in offspring (OR = 0.3, p < 0.01). Which of the following type of bias is most likely to have influenced these results?

[A] : Interviewer bias
[B] : Latency period
[C] : Recall bias
[D] : Survival bias
<|end|><|assistant|> The study in question is a retrospective survey, which means that the participants are being asked to recall past events or behaviors. In this case, the mothers are being asked to recall their prenatal consumption of folic acid. Recall bias is a type of bias that can occur in studies that rely on participants' memory of past events. It is a common issue in retrospective studies because participants may not remember past events accurately, or they may omit details they consider unimportant or embarrassing.

Interviewer bias (A) would be a concern if the interviewer's behavior or questioning influenced the participants' responses, but there is no indication in the scenario that this is the case.

Latency period (B) refers to the time between the exposure and the outcome. In this study, the latency period is the time between prenatal folic acid supplementation and the diagnosis of ASD in offspring. While this is an important consideration, it is not a type of bias but rather a factor that could influence the study's findings.

Survival bias (D) occurs when the study population is not representative of the general population due to differences in survival rates. In this case, the mothers of children with ASD may be more likely to participate in the study because they are more engaged with healthcare services, which could influence the results. However, the question does not provide enough information to conclude that survival bias is the most likely type of bias affecting the results.

Given the information provided, recall bias (C) is the most likely type of bias to have influenced the results because the study relies on participants' memory of their prenatal folic acid consumption.

So, the answer is [C]. Recall bias.<|end|>

His duty as a member of the team is to collect serum samples of the subjects every 4 hours and send them for analysis of serum drug levels. He is also supposed to collect, document and analyze the data. For one of the subjects, he notices that the subject is eliminating 0.5 mg of the drug every 4 hours. Which of the following anticoagulants did this patient most likely consume?

[A] : Warfarin
[B] : Enoxaparin
[C] : Fondaparinux
[D] : Apixaban
<|end|><|assistant|> To determine which anticoagulant the patient is most likely consuming based on the elimination rate of 0.5 mg every 4 hours, we need to consider the pharmacokinetics of each listed anticoagulant.

[A]. Warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist and has a very long half-life, typically ranging from 36 to 42 hours. It is not eliminated quickly and would not be expected to have a rapid elimination rate of 0.5 mg every 4 hours.

[B]. Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin with a half-life of approximately 1.3 to 1.9 hours. It is eliminated quickly by the kidneys, and its levels can drop significantly in a short period. However, the elimination rate of 0.5 mg every 4 hours is not consistent with the rapid clearance of enoxaparin.

[C]. Fondaparinux is a synthetic pentasaccharide that inhibits factor Xa. It has a half-life of about 17 hours and is also eliminated by the kidneys. The elimination rate of 0.5 mg every 4 hours is not consistent with the pharmacokinetics of fondaparinux.

[D]. Apixaban is a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) that inhibits factor Xa. It has a half-life of about 12 hours, which is consistent with the elimination rate of 0.5 mg every 4 hours. Apixaban is eliminated by both the kidneys and the liver, and its elimination rate fits the scenario described.

Given the information provided and the elimination rate of 0.5 mg every 4 hours, the anticoagulant that the patient is most likely consuming is apixaban.

So, the answer is [D].<|end|>

[A] : Glomerular crescents with macrophages
[B] : Matrix expansion with mesangial proliferation
[C] : Cortical thinning with tubular atrophy
[D] : Thickened glomerular capillary loops
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical picture described suggests that the 2-year-old girl has vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), which is a condition where urine flows retrograde, or backward, from the bladder into the ureters and sometimes up to the kidneys. This condition is often associated with recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) and can lead to renal damage if not treated.

The histologic findings in a kidney biopsy of a patient with VUR would likely reflect chronic changes due to the recurrent infections and the backward flow of urine. These changes can include:

- Interstitial fibrosis
- Tubular atrophy
- Cortical scarring

These findings are consistent with chronic pyelonephritis, which is a type of chronic kidney disease that can result from recurrent UTIs and VUR. The histologic changes do not typically include glomerular crescents with macrophages (A), which are more characteristic of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Matrix expansion with mesangial proliferation (B) is seen in IgA nephropathy, and thickened glomerular capillary loops (D) are seen in conditions like diabetic nephropathy or hypertensive nephrosclerosis.

Given the information provided, the most likely histologic finding would be cortical thinning with tubular atrophy (C), which reflects the chronic damage to the kidney tissue due to recurrent infections and reflux.

[A] : Calcium oxalate crystals
[B] : Hyaline casts
[C] : Urine ketones
[D] : Urate crystals

[A] : Hypertension
[B] : Ovarian cancer
[C] : Cervical cancer
[D] : Breast cancer
<|end|><|assistant|> Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) have several effects on a woman's health beyond their primary function of preventing pregnancy. One of the well-documented benefits of long-term use of COCPs is a reduced risk of ovarian cancer. The estrogen and progestin in COCPs are thought to suppress ovulation, which in turn reduces the number of times the ovarian epithelium is disrupted and needs to repair itself. This suppression of ovulation is believed to decrease the risk of malignant transformation of the ovarian epithelium, thereby reducing the risk of ovarian cancer.

COCPs have not been shown to have a protective effect against hypertension, cervical cancer, or breast cancer. In fact, COCPs can slightly increase the risk of breast cancer with long-term use, although the overall risk remains low.

So, the answer is [B].<|end|>

2025-12-10 16:50:51,322 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 10-year-old Caucasian female with Turner's syndrome underwent an abdominal imaging study and was discovered that the poles of her kidneys were fused inferiorly. Normal ascension of kidney during embryological development would be prevented by which of the following anatomical structures?

[A] : Superior mesenteric artery
[B] : Inferior mesenteric artery
[C] : Celiac artery
[D] : Splenic artery
<|end|><|assistant|> During embryological development, the kidneys ascend from the pelvis to their final position in the posterior abdominal wall. This process is guided by the growth of the gonads and the descent of the testes in males, which is accompanied by the descent of the kidneys. In females, the absence of testes means that the kidneys do not descend as far, and this can sometimes result in a condition known as renal fusion or renal fusion anomaly, where the lower poles of the kidneys fuse together.

The descent of the kidneys is facilitated by the presence of the gonadal veins and the gonadal arteries, which are connected to the inferior vena cava and the aorta, respectively. The inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) is an artery that arises from the abdominal aorta and supplies blood to the large intestine. It is located near the path of the descending testes in males and the descending kidneys in females.

In the case of a female with Turner's syndrome, the absence of the testes means that the normal descent of the kidneys is not accompanied by the descent of the gonads. The IMA, which is located anterior to the descending testes (or kidneys in females), could potentially impede the normal ascent of the kidneys if it were to grow abnormally or if there were an associated anomaly.

Therefore, the anatomical structure that would prevent the normal ascension of the kidneys during embryological development in a female with Turner's syndrome is the inferior mesenteric artery.

So, the answer is [B]. Inferior mesenteric artery.<|end|>

[A] : I, II
[B] : I, III, IV
[C] : I, V
[D] : III, IV
<|end|><|assistant|> After a splenectomy, patients are at increased risk for infections due to the spleen's role in filtering bacteria and mounting an immune response, particularly against encapsulated organisms. The vaccines recommended for asplenic or hyposplenic patients include those for Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae type b, and Neisseria meningitidis. - **N. meningitidis (III)**: Vaccination against Neisseria meningitidis is also recommended due to the increased risk of meningococcal disease in asplenic individuals.
- **S. pneumoniae (IV)**: The pneumococcal vaccine is crucial for preventing infections caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, which can be particularly severe in asplenic patients.

Vaccines for Tetanus (II) and Hepatitis B (V) are not specifically recommended for asplenic patients based on the increased risk of infection from encapsulated bacteria. Tetanus vaccination is part of routine immunization and is not directly related to asplenia. Hepatitis B vaccine is also part of routine immunization and is not specifically indicated for asplenic patients in the context of preventing infections from encapsulated bacteria.

So, the answer is [B]. I, III, IV.<|end|>

2025-12-10 16:51:04,011 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> Researchers are studying the inheritance pattern of mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) gene, the gene responsible for cystic fibrosis. It is believed that, in addition to the commonly found ΔF508 mutation, a novel mutation in this gene is found in a particular population under study. Which of the following would most likely suggest that these two loci have a high probability of being closely linked?

[A] : LOD Score < 1
[B] : LOD Score < 2
[C] : LOD Score > 3
[D] : LOD Score = 0
<|end|><|assistant|> The LOD (logarithm of the odds) score is a statistical estimate that measures the likelihood that two loci are close to each other on a chromosome and are therefore likely to be inherited together. This is also known as the LOD score for linkage.

- A LOD score of 3 or higher is generally considered strong evidence for linkage, meaning that the two loci are likely to be close to each other on the chromosome and are being inherited together.
- A LOD score of 1 to 2 suggests that linkage is possible but not definitively proven.
- A LOD score less than 1 suggests that linkage is unlikely.
- A LOD score of 0 indicates that there is no evidence of linkage.

Given that we are looking for a high probability of the two loci being closely linked, we would be looking for a high LOD score.

So, the answer is [C]. LOD Score > 3<|end|>

[B] : Cryotherapy ablation
[C] : Loop electrosurgical excision (LEEP)
[D] : Hysterectomy
<|end|><|assistant|> Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) I, also known as low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL), is a mild form of cervical dysplasia. It is often associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection and is considered a precursor to cervical cancer. However, CIN I has a good prognosis and often resolves spontaneously, especially in younger women.

The management of CIN I is conservative, especially in young women who may wish to preserve fertility. The recommended approach is close observation with repeat cytology (Pap smear) and HPV testing to monitor for any progression of the lesion. This is because the majority of CIN I lesions regress spontaneously within 12 to 24 months.

[A]. Close observation, pap smear screening at 6 and 12 months, and HPV DNA testing at 12 months - This is the standard approach for managing CIN I in young women, as it allows for monitoring of the lesion while preserving cervical tissue and fertility.

[B]. Cryotherapy ablation - This is a treatment option for CIN I, but it is not the first-line treatment for a young woman who may wish to preserve fertility.

[C]. Loop electrosurgical excision (LEEP) - This is another treatment option for CIN I, but like cryotherapy, it is not the first-line treatment for a young woman who may wish to preserve fertility.

[D]. Hysterectomy - This is a definitive treatment for CIN I but is not appropriate for a young woman who may wish to preserve fertility and has a lesion that may regress spontaneously.

Given the patient's age and the non-aggressive nature of CIN I, the most appropriate management is close observation with repeat cytology and HPV testing.

So, the answer is [A]. Close observation, pap smear screening at 6 and 12 months, and HPV DNA testing at 12 months.<|end|>

2025-12-10 16:51:20,501 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A clinical researcher is interested in creating a new drug for HIV patients. Darunavir has been particularly efficacious in recent patients; however, some have experienced an increased incidence of hyperglycemia. A new drug called DN501 is developed with the same mechanism of action as darunavir but fewer side effects. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of DN501?

[A] : Prevents viral transcription
[B] : Inhibits viral assembly
[C] : Inhibits viral entry
[D] : Prevents T-cell binding
<|end|><|assistant|> Darunavir is a protease inhibitor, which means it works by inhibiting the protease enzyme that HIV uses to cleave viral proteins for the assembly of new virions. This inhibition prevents the virus from maturing and assembling new infectious particles.

Given that DN501 is said to have the same mechanism of action as darunavir but with fewer side effects, it is reasonable to infer that DN501 is also a protease inhibitor. The options provided are:

[A]. Prevents viral transcription - This is not the mechanism of action for protease inhibitors.
[B]. Inhibits viral assembly - This is a consequence of inhibiting the protease enzyme, but it is not the direct mechanism.
[C]. Inhibits viral entry - This is the mechanism of action for entry inhibitors, not protease inhibitors.
[D]. Prevents T-cell binding - This is the mechanism of action for drugs that block the interaction between the virus and the host cell, such as fusion inhibitors.

Since DN501 is described as having the same mechanism of action as darunavir, the correct answer is that it inhibits the protease enzyme, which is necessary for viral assembly.

So, the answer is [B].<|end|>

2025-12-10 16:51:30,838 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> An investigator is studying the effect of drug X on the retinoblastoma (Rb) gene on chromosome 13 in endometrial cells. Endometrial cells obtained from study participants are plated on growth media and the distribution of cell cycle phase is measured with flow cytometry. Drug X, which is known to activate cyclin-dependent kinase 4, is administered to all the cells, and the distribution of cell cycle phase is measured again 1 hour later. Which of the following is most likely to result from the action of drug X on the Rb gene?

[A] : G1 phase arrest
[B] : Prophase I arrest
[C] : Initiation of S phase
[D] : Completion of G2 phase
<|end|><|assistant|> The retinoblastoma (Rb) gene is a tumor suppressor gene that plays a critical role in regulating the cell cycle. When the Rb protein is phosphorylated, it releases E2F transcription factors, which then activate genes necessary for the progression of the cell cycle from the G1 phase to the S phase.

Cyclin-dependent kinase 4 (CDK4) is one of the kinases that can phosphorylate the Rb protein. When CDK4 is activated, it can phosphorylate Rb, leading to the release of E2F transcription factors and the initiation of DNA synthesis, marking the transition from G1 to S phase.

Given that drug X is known to activate cyclin-dependent kinase 4, the most likely effect of drug X on the Rb gene in endometrial cells would be to phosphorylate Rb, leading to the initiation of the S phase.

So, the answer is [C]. Initiation of S phase.<|end|>

However, the journal editor returned the article, suggesting that it should be submitted as a case series instead. The editor made this suggestion to the authors for which of the following reasons?

[A] : No prevalence assessment
[B] : Low number of patients
[C] : Ascertainment bias
[D] : Lack of risk calculation
<|end|><|assistant|> The study described involves a small group of patients (14 patients), which is a relatively small sample size. In medical research, the number of patients in a study can significantly affect the reliability and generalizability of the results. A small number of patients can lead to a lack of statistical power, making it difficult to draw definitive conclusions or to generalize the findings to a larger population.

A case series is a type of observational study that tracks patients with a known exposure, such as a specific treatment or intervention, without a comparison group. It is often used when the number of patients is too small to conduct a larger, more robust study like a cohort or randomized controlled trial.

Given the small number of patients in this study, the journal editor likely suggested that the study be submitted as a case series because it would be more appropriate and potentially more publishable in this format. The case series would allow the authors to present a detailed report of their findings without the need for a larger sample size or a comparison group, which would be difficult to justify with only 14 patients.

2025-12-10 16:52:36,079 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 17-year-old female accidentally eats a granola bar manufactured on equipment that processes peanuts. She develops type I hypersensitivity-mediated histamine release, resulting in pruritic wheals on the skin. Which of the following layers of this patient's skin would demonstrate histologic changes on biopsy of her lesions?

[A] : Stratum corneum
[B] : Stratum granulosum
[C] : Stratum basale
[D] : Dermis
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient is experiencing a type I hypersensitivity reaction, which is an immediate allergic response. This type of reaction is mediated by IgE antibodies that bind to mast cells and basophils. When the allergen (in this case, peanut proteins) is encountered, it cross-links the bound IgE on the surface of mast cells and basophils, leading to degranulation and the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators.

Histamine release leads to increased vascular permeability and vasodilation, which are responsible for the redness and swelling seen in allergic reactions. The pruritic wheals on the skin are a result of this vasodilation and increased permeability.

The histologic changes in the skin due to a type I hypersensitivity reaction are typically seen in the dermis, where mast cells are located. The dermis is the layer of skin below the epidermis and above the subcutaneous tissue. It contains blood vessels, nerves, and connective tissue, and is where mast cells are found. When mast cells degranulate, they release histamine and other mediators that can cause the characteristic symptoms of an allergic reaction, such as redness, swelling, and itching.

So, the answer is [D]. Dermis.<|end|>

2025-12-10 16:52:54,646 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 48-year-old man seeks evaluation at a clinic with a complaint of breathlessness for the past couple of weeks. He says that he finds it difficult to walk a few blocks and has to rest. He also complains of a cough for the past 3 months, which is dry and hacking in nature. The medical history is relevant for an idiopathic arrhythmia for which he takes amiodarone daily. He is a non-smoker and does not drink alcohol. He denies any use of illicit drugs. The vital signs are as follows: heart rate 98/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.6°C (99.68°F), and blood pressure 132/70 mm Hg. The physical examination is significant for inspiratory crackles over the lung bases. An echocardiogram shows a normal ejection fraction. A chest radiograph is performed and shown below. Which of the following findings will most likely be noted on spirometry?

[A] : Decreased FEV1 and normal FVC
[B] : Decreased FEV1 and FVC with decreased FEV1/FVC ratio
[C] : Decreased FEV1 and FVC with normal FEV1/FVC ratio
[D] : Increased FEV1 and FVC
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with symptoms of breathlessness and a dry, hacking cough that have been persistent for a few weeks. The presence of inspiratory crackles over the lung bases on physical examination suggests the possibility of a pulmonary condition. The fact that the echocardiogram shows a normal ejection fraction makes a primary cardiac cause of the symptoms less likely.

Given the patient's history of taking amiodarone, it is important to consider the potential side effects of this medication. Amiodarone is known to cause pulmonary toxicity, which can manifest as interstitial lung disease or pulmonary fibrosis. These conditions can lead to restrictive lung disease, which is characterized by a reduction in lung volumes, including total lung capacity (TLC) and functional residual capacity (FRC).

In restrictive lung disease, both the forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) and the forced vital capacity (FVC) are reduced due to the decreased lung compliance. However, the reduction in FVC is typically proportionate to the reduction in FEV1, leading to a normal or even increased FEV1/FVC ratio. This is in contrast to obstructive lung diseases, where the FEV1 is disproportionately reduced compared to the FVC, resulting in a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio.

Given the clinical picture and the likely diagnosis of a restrictive lung disease secondary to amiodarone use, the spirometry would most likely show a decreased FEV1 and FVC with a normal FEV1/FVC ratio.

So, the answer is [C]. Decreased FEV1 and FVC with normal FEV1/FVC ratio.<|end|>

[D]. Reassurance and follow-up - While reassurance and follow-up are important, they are not sufficient as the sole next step in the management of an infant at risk for HIV infection.

She says that the shortness of breath is worse on exertion and improves with rest. While she could previously walk to the nearby store for her groceries, she now has to drive because she gets ''winded'' on the way. The patient was diagnosed with diabetes 5 years ago and is compliant with her medications. The medical history is otherwise unremarkable. The physical examination reveals gross ascites and visibly engorged periumbilical veins. Bilateral pitting edema is noted around the ankles. The finger-prick blood glucose level is 100 mg/dL. What is the mechanism of action of the anti-diabetic medication this patient is most likely taking?

[A] : Binding to the alpha subunit of the insulin receptor
[B] : Closure of ATP-sensitive K-channels in the pancreatic beta-cell
[C] : Increased gene expression of GLUT-4
[D] : Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient has diabetes and is experiencing worsening symptoms despite being compliant with her medications. The presence of gross ascites and visibly engorged periumbilical veins, along with bilateral pitting edema, suggests that she may have developed complications from her diabetes, such as diabetic nephropathy or heart failure, which can lead to fluid retention and ascites.

Given that her finger-prick blood glucose level is 100 mg/dL, which is within the normal range, it is likely that her diabetes is well-controlled with her current medication. The most common classes of anti-diabetic medications include:

[A]. Sulfonylureas, which work by binding to the alpha subunit of the insulin receptor, leading to increased insulin release from the pancreatic beta cells.
[B]. Metformin, which closes ATP-sensitive K-channels in the pancreatic beta-cell, leading to increased insulin release.
[C]. Thiazolidinediones (TZDs), which increase gene expression of GLUT-4, enhancing glucose uptake in peripheral tissues.
[D]. GLP-1 receptor agonists, which mimic the action of glucagon-like peptide-1, leading to increased insulin secretion and decreased glucagon secretion.

Considering the patient's symptoms and the fact that her blood glucose is well-controlled, it is unlikely that her diabetes is being managed with a medication that would cause hypoglycemia or other severe side effects. Sulfonylureas (A) can cause hypoglycemia, which is not indicated here. GLP-1 receptor agonists (D) are typically used in type 2 diabetes and can cause gastrointestinal side effects, which are not mentioned.

The most likely medication that would be used in a patient with well-controlled diabetes and without hypoglycemia is metformin (B), which is a first-line treatment for type 2 diabetes and works by closing ATP-sensitive K-channels in the pancreatic beta-cell, leading to increased insulin release.

So, the answer is [B]. Closure of ATP-sensitive K-channels in the pancreatic beta-cell.<|end|>

[A] : Endometrial sloughing and uterine contractions mediated by prostaglandin
[B] : Ascending infection of the uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, or surrounding tissue
[C] : Fluid-filled sac within the ovary
[D] : Hormone-sensitive smooth muscle tumor of the myometrium

Given the description of the pain and its timing in relation to the menstrual cycle, the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is the normal process of endometrial sloughing and uterine contractions mediated by prostaglandins.

So, the answer is [A].<|end|>

[B] : Retrograde migration up peripheral nerve axons
[C] : Reactivation of virus previously latent in dorsal root ganglia

[A]. Hematogenous dissemination to the meninges - This is a common route for viruses to enter the CNS, but it typically leads to meningitis rather than the acute neurological symptoms described.

[D]. Infection of oligodendrocytes and astrocytes - While some viruses can infect these cells, the acute presentation and the history of exposure suggest a more direct route of infection rather than one that involves these cells.

However, without a history of an animal bite, this route is less likely than reactivation of a latent virus in the dorsal root ganglia.

So, the answer is [C]. Reactivation of virus previously latent in dorsal root ganglia.<|end|>

[A] : Tinea versicolor
[B] : Albinism
[C] : Vitiligo
[D] : Melanoma
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with hypopigmented skin, which means there is a loss of pigment in the skin. The key finding from the biopsy is the absence of melanocytes in the epidermis. Melanocytes are the cells responsible for producing melanin, the pigment that gives color to the skin.

[A]. Tinea versicolor is a fungal infection of the skin that can cause hypopigmented or hyperpigmented patches, but it does not involve the absence of melanocytes.

[B]. Albinism is a genetic condition characterized by a complete or partial lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes. It is caused by a defect in the production of melanin by melanocytes.

[C]. Vitiligo is an autoimmune condition where the body's immune system attacks and destroys melanocytes, leading to the development of white patches on the skin.

[D]. Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes. It is not characterized by an absence of melanocytes but rather by the presence of abnormal and uncontrolled melanocytes.

Given that the biopsy shows an absence of melanocytes, the most likely diagnosis is vitiligo, as it is the condition that specifically involves the loss of melanocytes.

[B] : Coarctation of the aorta
[C] : Aortic stenosis
[D] : Transposition of great vessels

2. Brachiofemoral delay in the pulse: This indicates a delay in the pulse wave reaching the lower extremities, which is consistent with an obstruction in the aorta.

3. Auscultation findings: A loud S1, loud S2, and S4 are indicative of a stiff or hypertrophic left ventricle, which can be a response to increased afterload, such as from aortic stenosis or coarctation of the aorta.

5. Chest X-ray showing rib notching: This is a classic radiographic finding in coarctation of the aorta. The notching is caused by collateral circulation that develops around the narrowed segment of the aorta, eroding the inferior aspect of the ribs.

2025-12-10 16:54:57,758 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a progressively growing mass in his axilla. Physical examination shows nontender, right axillary, cervical, and inguinal lymphadenopathy. His serum calcium concentration is 15.1 mg/dL and parathyroid hormone (PTH) concentration is 9 pg/mL. A lymph node biopsy shows granuloma formation and large CD15-positive, CD30-positive cells with bilobed nuclei. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's laboratory findings?

[A] : Excessive intake of dietary ergocalciferol
[B] : Induction of focal osteolysis by tumor cells
[C] : Secretion of γ-interferon by activated T-lymphocytes
[D] : Production of PTH-related peptide by malignant cells
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with a mass in the axilla, recurrent low-grade fevers, weight loss, and lymphadenopathy. The lymph node biopsy shows granuloma formation and large CD15-positive, CD30-positive cells with bilobed nuclei, which are characteristic of Hodgkin lymphoma.

The elevated serum calcium concentration and low parathyroid hormone (PTH) concentration suggest a condition known as humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy (HHM). In HHM, malignant cells produce a substance that mimics the action of PTH, leading to increased calcium release from the bones and increased renal tubular reabsorption of calcium, without the actual presence of PTH.

The most common substance produced by malignant cells that causes HHM is PTH-related peptide (PTHrP). This peptide is structurally similar to PTH and can bind to the same receptors, leading to the same physiological effects as PTH, including hypercalcemia.

The other options can be ruled out as follows:
[A]. Excessive intake of dietary ergocalciferol (vitamin D) would not explain the low PTH concentration and the presence of malignant cells in the lymph node biopsy.
[B]. Induction of focal osteolysis by tumor cells could contribute to hypercalcemia, but it would not explain the low PTH concentration.
[C]. Secretion of γ-interferon by activated T-lymphocytes is not typically associated with hypercalcemia and is not indicated by the findings in this case.

Given the clinical presentation and the biopsy findings, the most likely explanation for the patient's laboratory findings is the production of PTH-related peptide by malignant cells.

So, the answer is [D]. Production of PTH-related peptide by malignant cells.<|end|>

2025-12-10 16:55:13,742 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 7-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician by his mother. She reports that the child develops severe sunburns every time the infant is exposed to sunlight. She has applied copious amounts of sunscreen to the infant but this has not helped the problem. On examination, there are multiple areas of reddened skin primarily in sun exposed areas. The child’s corneas appear irritated and erythematous. Which of the following processes is likely impaired in this patient?

[A] : Nucleotide excision repair
[B] : Non-homologous end joining
[C] : Homologous recombination
[D] : Mismatch repair
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical presentation of the infant with severe sunburns and reddened skin in sun-exposed areas, along with irritated and erythematous corneas, suggests a condition known as xeroderma pigmentosum (XP). XP is a rare genetic disorder characterized by an extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) rays from sunlight. This condition is caused by a defect in the nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway, which is responsible for repairing DNA damage induced by UV light.

The NER pathway is crucial for correcting DNA damage caused by UV radiation, which can lead to mutations and skin cancers if not properly repaired. In individuals with XP, mutations in the genes responsible for the NER pathway lead to an inability to repair UV-induced DNA damage effectively. This results in the clinical manifestations observed in the infant, such as severe sunburns and an increased risk of skin cancers.

The other options listed are different DNA repair mechanisms:

[B]. Non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) is a repair mechanism for double-strand breaks in DNA, which are not typically caused by UV light.
[C]. Homologous recombination (HR) is a repair mechanism for double-strand breaks in DNA, using a homologous sequence as a template for repair, and is also not primarily involved in repairing UV-induced damage.
[D]. Mismatch repair (MMR) corrects errors that occur during DNA replication, such as base-base mismatches and insertion-deletion loops, but it is not involved in repairing UV-induced DNA damage.

Given the clinical presentation and the role of the NER pathway in repairing UV-induced DNA damage, the impaired process in this patient is nucleotide excision repair.

So, the answer is [A]. Nucleotide excision repair.<|end|>

2025-12-10 16:55:30,240 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A group of researchers decided to explore whether the estimates of incidence and prevalence rates of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) were influenced by the number of years it took to examine administrative data. These estimates were not only based on hospital discharges, but also on physician billing codes. For study purposes, the researchers labeled incident cases at the initial occurrence of SLE diagnosis in the hospital database, while prevalent cases were those that were coded as harboring SLE at any time, with patients maintaining their diagnosis until death. Which statement is true regarding the relationship between incidence and prevalence rates during the time period that might be chosen for this specific study?

[A] : Incidence rates will be higher during shorter time periods than longer periods.
[B] : The prevalence of SLE during consecutively shorter time windows will be overestimated.
[C] : The inclusion of attack rates would increase incidence estimates in longer time periods.
[D] : The inclusion of attack rates would decrease incidence estimates in shorter time periods.
<|end|><|assistant|> Incidence rate refers to the number of new cases of a disease that develop in a population at risk during a specific time period. Prevalence rate, on the other hand, refers to the total number of cases of a disease in a population at a given time.

[A]. Incidence rates will be higher during shorter time periods than longer periods. This statement is not necessarily true. Incidence rates depend on the number of new cases occurring in the population, not the length of the time period. A longer time period could capture more new cases if the disease is common or if the population at risk is large.

[B]. The prevalence of SLE during consecutively shorter time windows will be overestimated. This statement is true. If you look at a shorter time window, you are more likely to capture all the cases that are present during that time, including those that are newly diagnosed and those that have been present for some time. This can lead to an overestimation of the prevalence because you are not accounting for the fact that some of the cases were present at the beginning of the time window and have been counted multiple times.

[C]. The inclusion of attack rates would increase incidence estimates in longer time periods. Attack rates refer to the proportion of a population that develops a disease during a specific time period. Including attack rates in the calculation of incidence would not necessarily increase incidence estimates in longer time periods; it would just provide a more accurate count of new cases.

[D]. The inclusion of attack rates would decrease incidence estimates in shorter time periods. This statement is not necessarily true. Including attack rates would provide a more accurate count of new cases, but it would not inherently decrease the incidence estimates.

So, the answer is [B].<|end|>

Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 111/50 mm Hg. She is responsive to painful stimuli. Lung examination shows bilateral rales. Abdominal examination shows a distended abdomen and intact abdominal surgical incisions. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis shows:
pH 7.44
pO2 54 mm Hg
pCO2 31 mm Hg
HCO3- 22 mm Hg
Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?"

[A] : Increase the FiO2
[B] : Increase the tidal volume
[C] : Increase PEEP
[D] : Increase the respiratory rate
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient is in the intensive care unit following emergent surgery for a small bowel perforation. She is on mechanical ventilation with a set FiO2 of 50%, tidal volume of 1000 mL, respiratory rate of 12/min, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 2.5 cm H2O. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows a pH of 7.44, pO2 of 54 mm Hg, pCO2 of 31 mm Hg, and HCO3- of 22 mm Hg.

The ABG results indicate that the patient is experiencing respiratory alkalosis, as evidenced by the low pCO2 and normal pH. This can occur due to hyperventilation, which may be a response to pain, anxiety, hypoxemia, or other factors. The low pO2 suggests that the patient is not adequately oxygenating despite the set FiO2, which could be due to a ventilation-perfusion mismatch or shunt.

Given the patient's clinical context and the ABG results, the best next step would be to address the hypoxemia. Increasing the FiO2 would increase the amount of oxygen the patient is breathing, which could help improve oxygenation. However, increasing the FiO2 also increases the risk of oxygen toxicity and should be done cautiously.

Increasing the tidal volume could potentially worsen the patient's condition by increasing the risk of lung injury due to overdistension (volutrauma) and could also lead to alveolar dead space ventilation if the patient's lung compliance is reduced.

Increasing PEEP can help improve oxygenation by recruiting collapsed alveoli and reducing shunt, but it can also increase intrathoracic pressure, which may negatively affect venous return and cardiac output, especially in a patient with a recent abdominal surgery.

Increasing the respiratory rate would further decrease pCO2, potentially exacerbating the respiratory alkalosis and not directly addressing the primary issue of hypoxemia.

Considering the patient's current state and the need to improve oxygenation without causing additional harm, the best next step would be to cautiously increase the FiO2 while monitoring for signs of oxygen toxicity and ensuring that the patient's oxygenation status improves.

So, the answer is [A]. Increase the FiO2.<|end|>

He has not seen a doctor since he became uninsured 2 years ago. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F). Abdominal examination shows mild, diffuse tenderness throughout the lower quadrants. The liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin, and the spleen is palpated 1–2 cm below the left costal margin. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 49/mm3 (N ≥ 500 mm3). Blood cultures grow acid-fast organisms. A PPD skin test shows 4 mm of induration. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?

[A] : Voriconazole
[B] : Amphotericin B and itraconazole
[C] : Erythromycin
[D] : Azithromycin and ethambutol
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms, including intermittent fever, nonproductive cough, malaise, decreased appetite, abdominal pain, and weight loss, along with the finding of acid-fast organisms in blood cultures, are suggestive of an infection with Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC), which is a common opportunistic infection in patients with AIDS, especially when the CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is below 50/mm3.

The PPD skin test showing 4 mm of induration is not diagnostic in this case because the patient's immunocompromised state due to AIDS can lead to a false-negative tuberculin skin test.

The treatment for disseminated MAC infection in AIDS patients typically includes a combination of antimycobacterial agents. The recommended regimen is a macrolide (such as azithromycin or clarithromycin) plus ethambutol, with or without a third agent such as rifabutin or streptomycin.

Voriconazole (choice A) is an antifungal medication used to treat invasive aspergillosis and other fungal infections, not mycobacterial infections. Amphotericin B and itraconazole (choice B) are also antifungal agents and are not appropriate for treating MA[C]. Erythromycin (choice C) is an antibiotic that is not effective against mycobacteria.

Therefore, the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition is azithromycin and ethambutol (choice D), which is the standard treatment for disseminated MAC infection in AIDS patients.

So, the answer is [D]. Azithromycin and ethambutol.<|end|>

2025-12-10 16:57:00,248 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician for a scheduled colposcopy. Two weeks ago, she had a routine Pap smear that showed atypical squamous cells. Colposcopy shows an area of white discoloration of the cervix with application of acetic acid solution. Biopsy of this area shows carcinoma-in-situ. Activation of which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this condition?

[A] : JAK2 tyrosine kinase
[B] : E2F transcription factors
[C] : Phosphoprotein p53
[D] : Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors
<|end|><|assistant|> Carcinoma in situ (CIS) is a pre-invasive form of cervical cancer where abnormal cells are found only in the first layer of cells lining the cervix (the ectocervix) and have not spread to other tissues. The pathogenesis of cervical carcinoma, including CIS, is strongly associated with persistent infection with high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) types.

HPV infection can lead to the integration of viral DNA into the host cell's DNA, which can disrupt the normal function of cellular proteins that control cell growth and division. One of the key proteins affected by HPV is the tumor suppressor protein p53. Normally, p53 plays a crucial role in preventing cancer formation by inducing cell cycle arrest, DNA repair, or apoptosis in response to DNA damage. However, when HPV integrates into the host genome, it can lead to the inactivation of p53.

The inactivation of p53 is a critical step in the development of cervical carcinoma. Without the proper function of p53, cells with damaged DNA can continue to divide and proliferate, leading to the accumulation of mutations and the development of cancer.

The other options listed do not directly relate to the pathogenesis of cervical carcinoma in situ:

[A]. JAK2 tyrosine kinase is associated with certain types of leukemia and myeloproliferative disorders, not cervical cancer.
[B]. E2F transcription factors are involved in cell cycle regulation, but they are not the primary factor in the pathogenesis of cervical carcinoma.
[D]. Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors are involved in cell cycle regulation and can act as tumor suppressors, but they are not the primary factor in the pathogenesis of cervical carcinoma.

So, the answer is [C]. Phosphoprotein p53.<|end|>
2025-12-10 16:57:00,248 - INFO - question 249/1273 answer:C correct_answer:B False
2025-12-10 16:57:08,567 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A research group has developed a low-cost diagnostic retinal imaging device for cytomegalovirus retinitis in a population of HIV-infected patients. In a pilot study of 50 patients, the imaging test detected the presence of CMV retinitis in 50% of the patients. An ophthalmologist slit lamp examination, which was performed for each patient to serve as the gold standard for diagnosis, confirmed a diagnosis of CMV retinitis in 20 patients that were found to be positive through imaging, as well as 1 patient who tested negative with the device. If the prevalence of CMV retinitis in the population decreases due to increased access to antiretroviral therapy, how will positive predictive value and negative predictive value of the diagnostic test be affected?

[A] : PPV decreases, NPV decreases
[B] : PPV decreases, NPV increases
[C] : PPV increases, NPV decreases
[D] : PPV unchanged, NPV unchanged
<|end|><|assistant|> The positive predictive value (PPV) of a test is the probability that subjects with a positive screening test truly have the disease. The negative predictive value (NPV) is the probability that subjects with a negative screening test truly don't have the disease.

In the scenario provided, the PPV is calculated as the number of true positives (patients with CMV retinitis confirmed by both the imaging test and the slit lamp examination) divided by the total number of positive test results (both true positives and false positives). The NPV is calculated as the number of true negatives (patients without CMV retinitis confirmed by the slit lamp examination) divided by the total number of negative test results (both true negatives and false negatives).

Initially, the PPV is 20 true positives out of 30 positive test results (20 true positives + 10 false positives), which is approximately 66.7%. The NPV is 1 true negative out of 20 negative test results (1 true negative + 19 false negatives), which is 5%.

If the prevalence of CMV retinitis decreases due to increased access to antiretroviral therapy, the number of true cases of CMV retinitis will decrease. This means that there will be fewer true positives and more false negatives.

As the number of true positives decreases, the PPV will decrease because the proportion of true positives among all positive test results will decrease. As the number of false negatives increases, the NPV will increase because the proportion of true negatives among all negative test results will increase.

So, the answer is [B]. PPV decreases, NPV increases.<|end|>

[C] : Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)
[D] : Refer to outpatient group therapy

The first-line treatment for delusional disorder is pharmacotherapy, typically with antipsychotic medications. However, since the question is asking for the best initial course of treatment and does not specify the need for medication, we can consider psychotherapy as an initial approach.

Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is an evidence-based treatment for a variety of mental health disorders, including delusional disorder. CBT can help the patient challenge and modify unhelpful beliefs and behaviors, improve coping strategies, and address any underlying issues that may contribute to the delusions.

Referring to outpatient group therapy could be beneficial for social support and to prevent isolation, but it may not directly address the patient's delusional beliefs.

Given the information provided and the absence of a need for immediate pharmacotherapy, CBT would be a reasonable initial treatment approach to help the patient manage her delusions and improve her functioning.

[B] : Sodium oxybate
[C] : Imipramine
[D] : Increase daytime naps

[C]. Imipramine - This is a tricyclic antidepressant that is sometimes used off-label to treat symptoms of narcolepsy, particularly cataplexy, but it is not the first-line treatment.

[D]. Increase daytime naps - While scheduled naps can be part of the management of narcolepsy, they are not a treatment per se and may not be sufficient to manage the symptoms on their own.

[B] : Dilation of the pampiniform plexus
[C] : Twisting of the spermatic cord
[D] : Imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis

Given the description of the mass and the fact that it transilluminates, the most likely cause of the mass is an imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis, leading to a hydrocele.

[D] : Bite cells
<|end|><|assistant|> The Beta-globin gene mutation that leads to a decrease in the translation of Beta-globin mRNA and results in thalassemia intermedia typically causes a reduction in the production of beta-globin chains. This imbalance in globin chain production leads to ineffective erythropoiesis and hemolysis, which in turn causes anemia.

2025-12-10 16:58:10,280 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A routine newborn screening test for phenylketonuria in a male neonate shows a serum phenylalanine concentration of 44 mg/dL (N < 20). He is started on a special diet and the hyperphenylalaninemia resolves. At a routine well-child examination 4 months later, the physician notices that he has persistent head lag. On examination, he has blue eyes, pale skin, blonde hair, and generalized hypotonia. His serum prolactin level is markedly elevated. Supplementation of which of the following substances is most likely to prevent further complications of this patient's condition?

[A] : Tyrosine
[B] : Pyridoxine
[C] : Thiamine
[D] : Tetrahydrobiopterin
<|end|><|assistant|> The newborn screening test result showing a serum phenylalanine concentration of 44 mg/dL, which is above the normal range, indicates phenylketonuria (PKU). PKU is an inherited metabolic disorder characterized by a deficiency in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which is responsible for converting phenylalanine to tyrosine. Without this enzyme, phenylalanine accumulates in the blood and can cause various health problems, including intellectual disability, if not treated.

The patient was started on a special diet to manage the hyperphenylalaninemia, which is the high level of phenylalanine in the blood. This diet typically involves restricting phenylalanine intake to prevent further accumulation. However, the patient still presents with symptoms such as head lag, blue eyes, pale skin, blonde hair, generalized hypotonia, and markedly elevated serum prolactin levels. These symptoms suggest that the patient may have a form of PKU that is responsive to tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) supplementation.

BH4 is a cofactor for phenylalanine hydroxylase and other enzymes involved in the metabolism of phenylalanine. Some individuals with PKU have a form of the disease that is responsive to BH4 because they have a deficiency in the enzyme that recycles BH4. Supplementation with BH4 can help to reduce phenylalanine levels in the blood and prevent the complications associated with PKU.

Tyrosine (option A) is a product of phenylalanine metabolism and is not typically supplemented in PKU patients because they can synthesize it from phenylalanine. Pyridoxine (option B) and Thiamine (option C) are not directly related to the treatment of PKU.

So, the answer is [D].<|end|>

The clinical picture is suggestive of a condition known as "mittelschmerz," which is German for "middle pain." Mittelschmerz is a term used to describe the lower abdominal pain that some women experience during ovulation, which typically occurs around the middle of the menstrual cycle. The pain can last from a few minutes to a few days and is usually unilateral. The fact that the pain is cyclical and has resolved on its own in the past supports this diagnosis.

Given the lack of evidence for an acute surgical condition, such as appendicitis (which would typically present with fever, leukocytosis, and more severe pain), and the absence of any signs of infection or other abnormalities on physical examination and laboratory studies, the most appropriate next step in management is reassurance. The patient should be informed that the pain is likely due to mittelschmerz and that it is self-limiting.

Methotrexate (choice A) is used for ectopic pregnancy, which is not indicated here as there is no evidence of pregnancy or ectopic pregnancy. Nitrofurantoin (choice B) is an antibiotic used for the treatment of urinary tract infections, which also does not fit the clinical picture. Referral for surgery (choice D) would be inappropriate without evidence of a surgical abdomen.

So, the answer is [C]. Reassurance.<|end|>

[A]. Salmonella enteritidis typically has a longer incubation period, usually 12 to 72 hours, and is often associated with poultry, eggs, and meat.

[B]. Listeria monocytogenes also has a longer incubation period, often 3 to 7 days, and is commonly associated with deli meats, hot dogs, and unpasteurized dairy products.

[D]. Vibrio cholerae causes cholera, which is characterized by profuse watery diarrhea, often described as "rice-water stools," and can lead to severe dehydration. The incubation period is typically 2 to 3 days, and it is usually associated with contaminated water or food in tropical climates.

2025-12-10 16:58:52,228 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by staff of the group home where he resides because of worsening confusion for the past week. He has a history of major depressive disorder and had an ischemic stroke 4 months ago. Current medications are aspirin and sertraline. He is lethargic and disoriented. His pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 135/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows moist oral mucosa, normal skin turgor, and no peripheral edema. While in the waiting room, he has a generalized, tonic-clonic seizure. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium of 119 mEq/L and an elevated serum antidiuretic hormone concentration. Which of the following sets of additional laboratory findings is most likely in this patient?
 $$$ Serum osmolality %%% Urine sodium %%% Serum aldosterone $$$

[A] : ↓ ↓ ↓
[B] : ↑ ↓ normal
[C] : ↓ ↑ ↑
[D] : ↓ ↑ ↓
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with confusion, a history of ischemic stroke, and a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The laboratory findings show hyponatremia (serum sodium of 119 mEq/L) and an elevated serum antidiuretic hormone (ADH) concentration. These findings suggest that the patient is likely suffering from the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).

In SIADH, there is an excessive release of ADH, which leads to water retention and dilutional hyponatremia. The body's response to the low serum sodium is to conserve sodium, which is mediated by the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Aldosterone, a hormone produced by the adrenal glands, promotes sodium reabsorption in the kidneys. Therefore, in SIADH, aldosterone levels would be expected to be elevated as the body attempts to correct the hyponatremia.

Serum osmolality would be low because of the dilutional effect of retained water. Urine sodium would be low because aldosterone promotes sodium reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to sodium being excreted in the urine despite the low serum sodium levels.

Given these considerations, the most likely set of additional laboratory findings in this patient would be:

- Serum osmolality: Low (↓)
- Urine sodium: Low (↓)
- Serum aldosterone: Elevated (↑)

So, the answer is [A]. ↓ ↓ ↑<|end|>

[B] : Short-acting benzodiazepines
[C] : Systematic desensitization
[D] : Cognitive behavioral therapy

[B]. Short-acting benzodiazepines can be used for the acute management of anxiety symptoms. However, they are not considered a definitive treatment for phobias because they do not address the underlying fear and can be habit-forming.

[C]. This can be an effective treatment for phobias, but it may not be the best definitive treatment for someone who is severely impaired by their phobia.

[D]. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is a type of psychotherapy that is highly effective for treating phobias. It combines cognitive therapy, which addresses the thoughts and beliefs that contribute to the phobia, with behavioral therapy, which involves changing the behavior associated with the phobia. CBT is considered a first-line treatment for phobias and can provide long-term relief from symptoms.

Given that the patient's phobia is causing significant impairment in her life, the best definitive treatment would be one that addresses both the cognitive and behavioral aspects of the phobia. CBT is the most comprehensive approach for this and is considered the gold standard for the treatment of phobias.

[A] : 0%
[B] : 25%
[C] : 50%
[D] : 100%
<|end|><|assistant|> Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder, which means that the gene causing hemophilia is located on the X chromosome. Males have one X and one Y chromosome (XY), while females have two X chromosomes (XX).

Since the male in the question has hemophilia A, he has the hemophilia gene on his X chromosome. His Y chromosome does not carry the gene for hemophilia. When he has children, he will pass on his Y chromosome to his sons, making them hemophilia-free, and his X chromosome with the hemophilia gene to his daughters, making them carriers if the other X chromosome is normal.

The wife of the male in question is unaffected, which means she has at least one normal X chromosome. Since she has three unaffected daughters, it is likely that she is not a carrier of the hemophilia gene, as carriers have a 50% chance of passing the gene to their children. However, without genetic testing, we cannot be certain.

For the second daughter, the probability that she is a carrier is the same as for any daughter of a hemophiliac father and an unaffected mother, assuming the mother is not a carrier. This is because each daughter has a 50% chance of inheriting the X chromosome with the hemophilia gene from her father and a 50% chance of inheriting the normal X chromosome from her mother.

So, the answer is [C]. 50%<|end|>

The patient is unable to repeat the sentence said to him on whisper testing. When a vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of the patient's forehead, it is heard equally on both ears. When the vibrating tuning fork is placed by the ear and then on the mastoid process, air conduction is greater than bone conduction. Which of the following structures is most likely impaired in this patient?

[A] : Tympanic membrane
[B] : Malleus
[C] : Incus
[D] : Cochlea
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms include progressively worsening hearing loss, difficulty understanding speech in noisy environments, tinnitus (ringing in the ears), and episodes of unsteadiness. These symptoms suggest a sensorineural hearing loss, which is often due to problems in the inner ear or the auditory nerve.

The whisper test is a simple screening test for hearing loss. The patient's inability to repeat the sentence indicates a hearing impairment. The tuning fork tests mentioned in the question are the Rinne and Weber tests.

The Rinne test compares air conduction (AC) to bone conduction (BC). Normally, air conduction is better than bone conduction (AC > BC), which is the case for this patient. This suggests that the problem is not with the outer or middle ear structures (tympanic membrane, malleus, or incus), as these would typically cause a conductive hearing loss where BC would be greater than AC.

The Weber test involves placing a vibrating tuning fork on the center of the forehead. In a normal hearing or sensorineural hearing loss, the sound is heard equally in both ears. However, in conductive hearing loss, the sound lateralizes to the affected ear. Since the sound is heard equally in both ears, this further supports that the problem is not with the outer or middle ear.

Given that the patient has sensorineural hearing loss and the tests performed do not indicate a conductive hearing loss, the most likely impaired structure is the cochlea, which is part of the inner ear and is responsible for converting sound waves into nerve impulses that the brain can interpret.

So, the answer is [D]. Cochlea.<|end|>

[C] : Abdominal ultrasound
[D] : Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of malabsorption, such as abdominal bloating, increased frequency of bulky, foul-smelling, and difficult-to-flush stools, as well as weight loss. The dull upper abdominal pain that worsens after meals could be indicative of gastric or duodenal issues, such as gastritis or peptic ulcer disease.

Given the patient's history of significant alcohol use, it is important to consider the possibility of chronic pancreatitis or pancreatic insufficiency, which can lead to malabsorption and steatorrhea (fatty stools). However, the symptoms could also be due to other gastrointestinal conditions such as celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease, or a malignancy.

The most appropriate next step in diagnosis would be to perform an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (Option D). This procedure would allow direct visualization of the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum, and it would enable the physician to take biopsies if necessary. This could help in diagnosing conditions such as gastritis, peptic ulcer disease, or malignancies.

An abdominal CT scan (Option A) could be useful in evaluating for masses or other structural abnormalities, but it would not provide the same level of detail about the mucosal surface or allow for biopsy.

Endoscopic ultrasonography (Option B) is a good tool for evaluating pancreatic pathology, but it is not the first-line investigation for the symptoms described.

Abdominal ultrasound (Option C) could be used to evaluate for gallstones or liver disease, but it is less sensitive than endoscopy for the evaluation of the upper gastrointestinal tract and would not provide information about the mucosal surface or allow for biopsy.

So, the answer is [D].<|end|>

[B] : Basal cell carcinoma
[C] : Seborrheic keratosis
[D] : Kaposi's sarcoma
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's history of significant sun exposure and the description of the lesion as a 2 cm dome-shaped plaque with a central keratin plug are characteristic of a keratoacanthoma. Kaposi's sarcoma is a vascular tumor associated with immunosuppression and presents as red to purple plaques or nodules, which is not consistent with the description of the lesion in this case.

2025-12-10 17:00:40,686 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 56-year-old man presents to his primary care doctor with intermittent chest pain. He reports a 2-month history of exertional chest pain that commonly arises after walking 5 or more blocks. He describes the pain as dull, burning, non-radiating substernal pain. His past medical history is notable for hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. He takes simvastatin and losartan. His temperature is 98.9°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 150/85 mmHg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 18/min. On exam, he is well-appearing and in no acute distress. S1 and S2 are normal. No murmurs are noted. An exercise stress test is performed to further evaluate the patient’s pain. Which of the following substances is released locally to increase coronary blood flow during exertion?

[A] : Adenosine
[B] : Inorganic phosphate
[C] : Prostaglandin E2
[D] : Transforming growth factor beta
<|end|><|assistant|> During exertion, the myocardium requires more oxygen due to the increased workload. The body has a mechanism to increase blood flow to the heart muscle during times of increased demand, such as exercise. One of the key substances involved in this process is adenosine.

Adenosine is a byproduct of ATP metabolism in the heart and is released in response to increased energy demand. It has a potent vasodilatory effect on the coronary arteries, which leads to an increase in blood flow to the myocardium. This is an important protective mechanism to ensure that the heart muscle receives enough oxygen and nutrients during times of stress or increased workload.

Inorganic phosphate is not directly involved in the regulation of coronary blood flow. Prostaglandin E2 does have vasodilatory effects, but it is not the primary mediator for increasing coronary blood flow during exertion. Transforming growth factor beta is involved in cell growth and differentiation, not in the acute regulation of blood flow during exercise.

So, the answer is [A].<|end|>

What is the most likely explanation for this patient's deterioration in renal function?

[A] : Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
[B] : Ischemic acute tubular necrosis
[C] : Nephrotoxic acute tubular necrosis
[D] : Toxic tubulointerstitial nephritis

Nephrotoxic acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is caused by direct toxins to the kidney, such as heavy metals or contrast agents, and also does not typically present with eosinophilic infiltration.

[C] : Fluoxetine
[D] : Psychodynamic psychotherapy
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient is experiencing a specific phobia, which is an intense, irrational fear of a specific object, situation, or activity that is generally not harmful. The best treatment for specific phobias is cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), which is a type of psychotherapy that helps patients understand the thoughts and feelings that influence behaviors. CBT is often used to treat anxiety disorders, including phobias, and involves exposing the patient to the feared object or situation in a controlled and gradual way, helping them to develop coping strategies and eventually overcome the fear.

Psychodynamic psychotherapy (D) is a form of depth psychology, the primary focus of which is to reveal the unconscious content of a client's psyche in an effort to alleviate psychic tension. While it can be helpful for some individuals, it is not the most evidence-based treatment for specific phobias.

So, the answer is [B]. Cognitive behavioral therapy.<|end|>

2025-12-10 17:01:28,986 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 75-year-old man presents to a medical clinic for evaluation of a large, tense, pruritic bulla on his inner thighs, abdomen, and lower abdomen. A skin biopsy is performed, which shows an epidermal basement membrane with immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies and linear immunofluorescence. Which of the following is the most likely cell junction to which the antibodies bind?

[A] : Desmosomes
[B] : Gap junctions
[C] : Hemidesmosomes
[D] : Tight junctions
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical presentation of a large, tense, pruritic bulla on the inner thighs, abdomen, and lower abdomen, along with the skin biopsy findings of an epidermal basement membrane with IgG antibodies and linear immunofluorescence, is suggestive of bullous pemphigoid. Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune blistering skin disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies against components of the hemidesmosomes, which are structures that anchor the epidermis to the basement membrane.

Hemidesmosomes are specialized cell junctions that provide structural integrity to the skin by connecting the basal cells of the epidermis to the underlying basement membrane. In bullous pemphigoid, the autoantibodies typically target proteins such as BP180 (also known as type XVII collagen) and BP230, which are components of the hemidesmosomes.

Desmosomes are another type of cell junction that provide adhesion between cells, but they are not the target in bullous pemphigoid. Gap junctions are involved in cell-to-cell communication and are not related to the pathology of bullous pemphigoid. Tight junctions are involved in creating a barrier to prevent the passage of substances between cells, and they are also not the target in bullous pemphigoid.

Given the information provided and the typical pathology of bullous pemphigoid, the antibodies in this case are most likely binding to the hemidesmosomes.

So, the answer is [C]. Hemidesmosomes.<|end|>

[B] : Preferential dilatation of capacitance vessels
[C] : Inhibition of aldosterone-mediated sodium reabsorption
[D] : Reduction in myocardial contractility

[B]. Preferential dilatation of capacitance vessels - This is the mechanism of action of nitrates, which help to reduce preload by dilating veins.

[D]. Reduction in myocardial contractility - This is the mechanism of action of beta-blockers, which can reduce the heart rate and the force of contraction, thus reducing the workload on the heart.
